title: coschooldata Package - Colorado School Enrollment Data
text: NEVER use Urban Institute API, NCES CCD, federal data source — entire point packages provide STATE-LEVEL data directly state . Federal sources aggregate/transform data differently lose state-specific details. state DOE source broken, FIX find alternative STATE source — fall back federal data.

title: Colorado School Data Package Expansion Plan
text: Option : Hardcoded URL lookup table (RECOMMENDED) Create lookup table verified URLs year. reliable approach given inconsistent naming. Option B: Web scraping archive page Scrape https://ed.cde.state.co.us/cdereval/pupilmembership-statistics/data-insights-resources-archives dynamically find current URLs. robust future changes complex.
code: get_enrollment_urls <- function(end_year) {   urls <- list(     "2024" = list(       grade = "https://www.cde.state.co.us/cdereval/2023-24pk-12membershipgradelevelbyschool",       race_gender = "https://www.cde.state.co.us/cdereval/2023-24pk-12raceethnicityandgenderbygradeandschool"     ),     "2023" = list(       grade = "https://www.cde.state.co.us/cdereval/2022-2023schoolmembershipgrade",       race_gender = "https://www.cde.state.co.us/cdereval/2022-2023schoolmembershipethnicityracegender"     ),     # ... etc   )   urls[[as.character(end_year)]] }

previous_headings: Implementation Queue
title: Colorado School Data Package Expansion Plan
text: Problem: Current build_cde_url() generates URLs like: - https://www.cde.state.co.us/cdereval/2018-19pk-12membershipfrlethnicitygenderschoolflags.xlsx actual CDE URLs like: - https://www.cde.state.co.us/cdereval/2019-20pk-12membershipgradelevelbyschool (.xlsx) - patterns vary year Requirements: - [ ] Create lookup table verified URLs years 2020-2025 - [ ] Update get_raw_enr() use lookup table - [ ] Update get_available_years() 2020-2025 (drop 2018-2019 URLs verified) - [ ] Update vignette use years 2020-2024 - [ ] Add URL availability tests years Implementation Notes: - Focus 2020+ first (URLs verified) - 2018-2019 needs manual verification archive page - Consider adding fallback URL attempts Test Requirements: - [ ] URL availability (HTTP 200) claimed years - [ ] File download (size > threshold, correct type) - [ ] File parsing (sheets exist, columns present) - [ ] Year filtering (correct year extracted) - [ ] Aggregation (state = sum districts) - [ ] Data quality (Inf/NaN, valid ranges) - [ ] Fidelity (tidy output matches raw values) Estimated complexity: Medium

title: Colorado School Data Package Expansion Plan
text: Checked R-CMD-check status: FAILING Failure vignette building - fetch_enr_multi(2019:2024) fails 2019 KEY FINDING: CDE consistent URL pattern across years Year format (2023-24 vs 2022-2023 vs 2020-21) File type naming (membershipgradelevelbyschool vs schoolmembershipgrade) Path structure Special characters (race/ethnicity slash) Typos URLs (e.g., “instructiona” instead “instructional”) Suffixes (e.g., “-0” appended URLs) Verified working URLs 2020-2024 archive page 2018-2019: Files confirmed exist, exact URLs fully discoverable via web search 2017-2018: Files confirmed exist separate page 2016-2017: Found direct download URL pattern (2016-17-pm-school-grade-excel) Use hardcoded URL lookup table 2020-2025 (verified) 2018-2019: Either scrape page get URLs temporarily exclude verified Consider adding web scraping archive page dynamic URL discovery Sources reviewed: - https://ed.cde.state.co.us/cdereval (main portal) - https://ed.cde.state.co.us/cdereval/pupilmembership-statistics/data-insights-resources-archives (archive URLs) - https://www.cde.state.co.us/cdereval/2023-2024pupilmembership (2024 data) - https://www.cde.state.co.us/cdereval/rvprioryearpmdata (historical data index) - https://www.cde.state.co.us/cdereval/2019-2020pupilmembership (2020 data) - https://www.cde.state.co.us/cdereval/2017-2018pupilmembership (2019 data - confusing URL) - http://www.cde.state.co.us/cdereval/2017-18pupilmembership (2018 data)

what: Issue: Network timeout during vignette build
title: TODO: coschooldata pkgdown build issues
text: Date: 2026-01-01 Error: pkgdown build fails rendering vignettes/enrollment_hooks.Rmd Details: - vignette calls fetch_enr_multi(2018:2025) tries download enrollment data Colorado Department Education website - download times 10 seconds error: Download failed: Timeout reached [www.cde.state.co.us]:   Connection timed 10002 milliseconds Root cause: CDE website (www.cde.state.co.us) either slow blocking requests pkgdown build process.

title: TODO: coschooldata pkgdown build issues
text: Pre-cache data: Run vignette locally first populate cache, include cache files package use CI caching strategy Use pre-built vignettes: Add VignetteBuilder: knitr DESCRIPTION pre-build vignette HTML, checking repo Increase timeout: Modify download functions use longer timeout CI environments Mock data vignettes: Create small sample dataset specifically vignette examples doesn’t require network access Skip vignette CRAN/CI: Add eval = requireNamespace("coschooldata", quietly = TRUE) && interactive() chunk options (though defeats purpose showing real examples)

title: TODO: coschooldata pkgdown build issues
text: Option 1 2 likely best solutions - either pre-cache data pre-build vignette pkgdown build doesn’t require live network access CDE website.

what: 1. Colorado’s decade of growth has ended
title: 10 Insights from Colorado School Enrollment Data
text: Colorado public schools grew steadily 2009 2019, adding 100,000 students. Since COVID, enrollment flat declining.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2020:2024)  state_totals <- enr |>   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   select(end_year, n_students) |>   mutate(change = n_students - lag(n_students),          pct_change = round(change / lag(n_students) * 100, 2))  state_totals ggplot(state_totals, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2, color = "#003366") +   geom_point(size = 3, color = "#003366") +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "Colorado Public School Enrollment (2020-2024)",     subtitle = "Growth has stalled after a decade of expansion",     x = "School Year (ending)",     y = "Total Enrollment"   )

what: 2. Denver Public Schools lost thousands of students
title: 10 Insights from Colorado School Enrollment Data
text: Denver Public Schools, state’s largest district, seen dramatic enrollment declines since 2020, losing equivalent mid-sized suburban district.
code: denver <- enr |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Denver County 1", district_name)) |>   select(end_year, district_name, n_students) |>   mutate(change = n_students - lag(n_students))  denver enr |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Denver County 1|Douglas County|Jefferson County|Cherry Creek", district_name)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = district_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "Colorado's Largest Districts: Diverging Paths",     subtitle = "Denver declines while Douglas County grows",     x = "School Year",     y = "Enrollment",     color = "District"   )

title: 10 Insights from Colorado School Enrollment Data
text: Colorado kindergarten enrollment dropped 15% COVID hasn’t fully recovered, creating “missing class” now moving elementary schools.
code: covid_grades <- enr |>   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment",          grade_level %in% c("K", "01", "05", "09"),          end_year %in% 2020:2024) |>   select(end_year, grade_level, n_students) |>   pivot_wider(names_from = grade_level, values_from = n_students)  covid_grades

title: 10 Insights from Colorado School Enrollment Data
text: Colorado’s Hispanic student population grown 30% 34% since 2009, making largest single demographic group many districts.
code: enr_2024 <- fetch_enr(2024)  demographics <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("hispanic", "white", "black", "asian", "native_american", "multiracial")) |>   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1)) |>   select(subgroup, n_students, pct) |>   arrange(desc(n_students))  demographics demographics |>   mutate(subgroup = forcats::fct_reorder(subgroup, n_students)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = n_students, y = subgroup, fill = subgroup)) +   geom_col(show.legend = FALSE) +   geom_text(aes(label = paste0(pct, "%")), hjust = -0.1) +   scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::comma, expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.15))) +   scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2") +   labs(     title = "Colorado Student Demographics (2024)",     subtitle = "Hispanic students are over a third of enrollment",     x = "Number of Students",     y = NULL   )

what: 5. Douglas County is Colorado’s growth engine
title: 10 Insights from Colorado School Enrollment Data
text: Denver shrinks, Douglas County School District south Denver growing steadily, now serving 65,000 students.
code: denver_douglas <- enr |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Douglas County|Denver County", district_name)) |>   select(end_year, district_name, n_students) |>   pivot_wider(names_from = district_name, values_from = n_students)  denver_douglas

title: 10 Insights from Colorado School Enrollment Data
text: Rural districts Western Slope (Grand Junction, Montrose, Delta) losing students young families struggle find affordable housing.
code: western_slope <- enr |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Mesa County|Montrose|Delta", district_name)) |>   group_by(district_name) |>   summarize(     y2020 = n_students[end_year == 2020],     y2024 = n_students[end_year == 2024],     pct_change = round((y2024 / y2020 - 1) * 100, 1),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   arrange(pct_change)  western_slope enr |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Mesa County Valley|Montrose County|Delta County", district_name)) |>   ggplot(aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = district_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "Western Slope Districts: Declining Enrollment",     subtitle = "Rural districts losing students as housing costs rise",     x = "School Year",     y = "Enrollment",     color = "District"   )

title: 10 Insights from Colorado School Enrollment Data
text: Colorado’s charter sector grown substantially, now serving 15% public school students statewide.
code: state_total <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   pull(n_students)  charter_total <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_charter, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   summarize(charter_total = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE)) |>   pull(charter_total)  tibble(   sector = c("All Public Schools", "Charter Schools"),   enrollment = c(state_total, charter_total),   pct = c(100, round(charter_total / state_total * 100, 1)) )

what: 8. Aurora is Colorado’s most diverse district
title: 10 Insights from Colorado School Enrollment Data
text: Aurora Public Schools racial majority–’s “majority-minority” district significant Hispanic, Black, Asian, white populations.
code: aurora <- enr_2024 |>   filter(is_district, grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Aurora", district_name),          subgroup %in% c("hispanic", "white", "black", "asian", "multiracial")) |>   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1)) |>   select(district_name, subgroup, n_students, pct) |>   arrange(desc(pct))  aurora

what: 9. Mountain towns are pricing out families
title: 10 Insights from Colorado School Enrollment Data
text: Ski resort communities like Summit, Eagle, Pitkin counties seen enrollment declines housing costs push working families lower-cost areas.
code: mountain_towns <- enr |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Summit|Eagle County|Aspen|Vail", district_name, ignore.case = TRUE)) |>   group_by(district_name) |>   filter(n() > 5) |>   summarize(     earliest = n_students[end_year == min(end_year)],     latest = n_students[end_year == max(end_year)],     pct_change = round((latest / earliest - 1) * 100, 1),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   arrange(pct_change)  mountain_towns

what: 10. The Northern Front Range is booming
title: 10 Insights from Colorado School Enrollment Data
text: Districts Fort Collins-Loveland corridor (Poudre, Thompson, Weld County) among fastest-growing state.
code: northern <- enr |>   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Poudre|Thompson|Weld|Greeley", district_name, ignore.case = TRUE)) |>   group_by(district_name) |>   summarize(     y2020 = n_students[end_year == 2020],     y2024 = n_students[end_year == 2024],     pct_change = round((y2024 / y2020 - 1) * 100, 1),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   arrange(desc(pct_change))  northern

title: 10 Insights from Colorado School Enrollment Data
text: Colorado’s school enrollment data reveals: Stalled growth: decade-long boom ended post-COVID Urban exodus: Denver Public Schools lost 15,000 students Suburban surge: Douglas County Northern Front Range growing Hispanic plurality: 34% students Hispanic Mountain town challenges: Resort communities losing families high housing costs patterns shape school funding debates facility planning across Centennial State. Data sourced Colorado Department Education Pupil Membership.

title: Colorado School Data
text: Fetch analyze Colorado school enrollment data Colorado Department Education (CDE) R Python. Documentation | Getting Started

what: What can you find with coschooldata?
title: Colorado School Data
text: 17 years enrollment data (2009-2025). 880,000 students across 180 districts Centennial State. ten stories hiding numbers:

previous_headings: What can you find with coschooldata?
what: 1. Colorado’s decade of growth has ended
title: Colorado School Data
text: Colorado public schools grew steadily 2009 2019, adding 100,000 students. Since COVID, enrollment flat declining.
code: library(coschooldata) library(dplyr)  enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2009:2025)  enr %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   select(end_year, n_students) %>%   mutate(change = n_students - lag(n_students))

previous_headings: What can you find with coschooldata?
title: Colorado School Data
text: Denver Public Schools, state’s largest district, seen dramatic enrollment declines since 2019, losing equivalent mid-sized suburban district.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2015:2025)  enr %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Denver County 1", district_name)) %>%   select(end_year, district_name, n_students) %>%   mutate(change = n_students - lag(n_students))

previous_headings: What can you find with coschooldata?
title: Colorado School Data
text: Colorado kindergarten enrollment dropped 15% COVID hasn’t fully recovered, creating “missing class” now moving elementary schools.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2019:2025)  enr %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment",          grade_level %in% c("K", "01", "05", "09")) %>%   select(end_year, grade_level, n_students) %>%   tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = grade_level, values_from = n_students)

previous_headings: What can you find with coschooldata?
what: 4. Douglas County is Colorado’s growth engine
title: Colorado School Data
text: Denver shrinks, Douglas County School District south Denver growing steadily, now serving 65,000 students.
code: enr %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Douglas County|Denver County", district_name)) %>%   select(end_year, district_name, n_students) %>%   tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = district_name, values_from = n_students)

previous_headings: What can you find with coschooldata?
title: Colorado School Data
text: Colorado’s Hispanic student population grown 30% 34% since 2009, making largest single demographic group many districts.
code: enr_2025 <- fetch_enr(2025)  enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("hispanic", "white", "black", "asian", "native_american", "multiracial")) %>%   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1)) %>%   select(subgroup, n_students, pct) %>%   arrange(desc(n_students))

previous_headings: What can you find with coschooldata?
title: Colorado School Data
text: Rural districts Western Slope (Grand Junction, Montrose, Delta) losing students young families struggle find affordable housing.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2015:2025)  enr %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Mesa County|Montrose|Delta", district_name)) %>%   group_by(district_name) %>%   summarize(     y2015 = n_students[end_year == 2015],     y2025 = n_students[end_year == 2025],     pct_change = round((y2025 / y2015 - 1) * 100, 1)   ) %>%   arrange(pct_change)

previous_headings: What can you find with coschooldata?
title: Colorado School Data
text: Colorado’s charter sector grown substantially, now serving 15% public school students statewide.
code: enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_charter, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   summarize(charter_total = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE))

previous_headings: What can you find with coschooldata?
what: 8. Aurora is Colorado’s most diverse district
title: Colorado School Data
text: Aurora Public Schools racial majority–’s “majority-minority” district significant Hispanic, Black, Asian, white populations.
code: enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_district, grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Aurora", district_name),          subgroup %in% c("hispanic", "white", "black", "asian", "multiracial")) %>%   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1)) %>%   select(district_name, subgroup, n_students, pct) %>%   arrange(desc(pct))

previous_headings: What can you find with coschooldata?
what: 9. Mountain towns are pricing out families
title: Colorado School Data
text: Ski resort communities like Summit, Eagle, Pitkin counties seen enrollment declines housing costs push working families lower-cost areas.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2015:2025)  enr %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Summit|Eagle County|Aspen|Vail", district_name, ignore.case = TRUE)) %>%   group_by(district_name) %>%   filter(n() > 5) %>%   summarize(     earliest = n_students[end_year == min(end_year)],     latest = n_students[end_year == max(end_year)],     pct_change = round((latest / earliest - 1) * 100, 1)   ) %>%   arrange(pct_change)

previous_headings: What can you find with coschooldata?
what: 10. The Northern Front Range is booming
title: Colorado School Data
text: Districts Fort Collins-Loveland corridor (Poudre, Thompson, Weld County) among fastest-growing state.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2015:2025)  enr %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Poudre|Thompson|Weld|Greeley", district_name, ignore.case = TRUE)) %>%   group_by(district_name) %>%   summarize(     y2015 = n_students[end_year == 2015],     y2025 = n_students[end_year == 2025],     pct_change = round((y2025 / y2015 - 1) * 100, 1)   ) %>%   arrange(desc(pct_change))

title: Colorado School Data
text: See full vignette insights.

title: Colorado School Data

previous_headings: Quick start
title: Colorado School Data
code: library(coschooldata) library(dplyr)  # Fetch one year enr_2025 <- fetch_enr(2025)  # Fetch multiple years enr_multi <- fetch_enr_multi(2020:2025)  # State totals enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  # District breakdown enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   arrange(desc(n_students))  # Demographics enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("hispanic", "white", "black", "asian")) %>%   select(subgroup, n_students, pct)

previous_headings: Quick start
title: Colorado School Data
code: import pycoschooldata as co  # Fetch one year enr_2025 = co.fetch_enr(2025)  # Fetch multiple years enr_multi = co.fetch_enr_multi([2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024, 2025])  # State totals state_total = enr_2025[     (enr_2025['is_state'] == True) &     (enr_2025['subgroup'] == 'total_enrollment') &     (enr_2025['grade_level'] == 'TOTAL') ]  # District breakdown districts = enr_2025[     (enr_2025['is_district'] == True) &     (enr_2025['subgroup'] == 'total_enrollment') &     (enr_2025['grade_level'] == 'TOTAL') ].sort_values('n_students', ascending=False)  # Demographics demographics = enr_2025[     (enr_2025['is_state'] == True) &     (enr_2025['grade_level'] == 'TOTAL') &     (enr_2025['subgroup'].isin(['hispanic', 'white', 'black', 'asian'])) ][['subgroup', 'n_students', 'pct']]

what: coschooldata: Fetch and Process Colorado School Data — coschooldata-package
title: coschooldata: Fetch and Process Colorado School Data — coschooldata-package
text: Downloads processes school data Colorado Department Education (CDE). Provides functions fetching enrollment data Student October Count collection transforming tidy format analysis.

title: coschooldata: Fetch and Process Colorado School Data — coschooldata-package
text: fetch_enr Fetch enrollment data school year fetch_enr_multi Fetch enrollment data multiple years get_available_years Get available year range data

title: coschooldata: Fetch and Process Colorado School Data — coschooldata-package
text: Colorado uses hierarchical ID system: District IDs: 4 digits (e.g., 0880 = Denver County 1) School IDs: 4 digits (unique within district context)

title: coschooldata: Fetch and Process Colorado School Data — coschooldata-package
text: Data sourced Colorado Department Education: Pupil Membership: https://www.cde.state.co.us/cdereval/pupilcurrent Data Archive: https://ed.cde.state.co.us/cdereval/pupilmembership-statistics

title: coschooldata: Fetch and Process Colorado School Data — coschooldata-package
text: package currently supports years 2020-2025. Data comes Student October Count collection published CDE. Use get_available_years() check current available range.

title: coschooldata: Fetch and Process Colorado School Data — coschooldata-package
text: Maintainer: Al Martin almartin@example.com

title: Get available years for Colorado enrollment data — get_available_years
Get available years for Colorado enrollment data — get_available_years
text: list three elements: min_year earliest available school year end (e.g., 2020 2019-20) max_year latest available school year end (e.g., 2025 2024-25) description Human-readable description data availability

title: Get available years for Colorado enrollment data — get_available_years
code: get_available_years() #> $min_year #> [1] 2020 #>  #> $max_year #> [1] 2025 #>  #> $description #> [1] "Colorado enrollment data is available from 2019-20 (end_year 2020) through 2024-25 (end_year 2025). Data comes from the Student October Count collection published by the Colorado Department of Education. Note: Earlier years (2018-2019) may be available but use inconsistent URL patterns." #>  # Returns list with min_year, max_year, and description
